items.description: Analyze repository structure and define project scaffold
items.acceptance_criteria: A document (MODULE_MAP.md) listing every planned module/file, its purpose, and inter-module dependencies. Directory structure for src/, tests/, figures/, results/ created.

items.description: Conduct literature review on N-body gravitational simulation methods
items.acceptance_criteria: Web search performed for at least 15 queries covering: N-body simulation algorithms, symplectic integrators, Barnes-Hut treecode, gravitational softening, adaptive time-stepping, and energy conservation in numerical orbits. Summary document (LITERATURE_REVIEW.md) written with at least 10 key findings organized by topic.

items.description: Survey existing open-source N-body simulation codebases
items.acceptance_criteria: Web search performed for open-source gravity simulators (e.g., REBOUND, Gadget, NBODY6, PyNbody). At least 5 codebases surveyed with notes on language, algorithms used, and design patterns. Summary appended to LITERATURE_REVIEW.md.

items.description: Populate sources.bib with BibTeX entries for all consulted sources
items.acceptance_criteria: File sources.bib exists at repo root with valid BibTeX entries. At least 12 relevant references cited including: Aarseth (2003) gravitational N-body simulations, Barnes & Hut (1986) treecode, Verlet (1967), Wisdom & Holman (1991) symplectic mapping, Dehnen & Read (2011) N-body review, and Springel (2005) cosmological simulations. Each entry has author, title, year, and journal/source fields.

items.description: Formalize mathematical formulation of the N-body gravitational problem
items.acceptance_criteria: Document (FORMULATION.md) with: Newton's law of gravitation formula, equations of motion for N particles, definition of gravitational potential energy, total energy (kinetic + potential), linear and angular momentum conservation laws, and dimensional analysis. All equations typeset in LaTeX-compatible markdown.

items.description: Compare numerical integration methods and select approaches for implementation
items.acceptance_criteria: Table comparing at least 5 integration methods (Forward Euler, Symplectic Euler, Leapfrog/Verlet, RK4, Yoshida 4th-order) on: order of accuracy, symplecticity, time-reversibility, cost per step, and energy drift behavior. Justification for selecting at least 3 methods to implement. References to sources.bib entries included.

items.description: Implement particle data structures and initialization routines
items.acceptance_criteria: Python module (src/body.py or src/particle.py) with: Body/Particle class storing mass, position (2D or 3D vector), velocity, acceleration. Factory functions for creating circular Kepler orbits and random N-body configurations. Unit tests pass confirming correct initialization of at least 3 test cases.

items.description: Implement direct-summation O(N^2) pairwise gravitational force computation
items.acceptance_criteria: Python module (src/force.py) computing gravitational acceleration on each body via direct pairwise summation. Newton's third law exploited (each pair computed once). Unit test verifying force on a 2-body system matches analytical F = Gm1m2/r^2 to within 1e-12 relative error. Complexity confirmed as O(N^2) by counting force evaluations.

items.description: Implement Forward Euler integrator as baseline
items.acceptance_criteria: Python module (src/integrators.py) with a forward_euler(bodies, dt) function. Integration of a circular Kepler orbit for 1 period shows visible energy drift (>1% relative error). Test confirms positions update correctly for a single timestep against hand calculation.

items.description: Implement energy and momentum conservation diagnostics
items.acceptance_criteria: Python module (src/diagnostics.py) computing: total kinetic energy, total gravitational potential energy, total energy, total linear momentum vector, and total angular momentum vector. Unit tests verify conservation quantities are computed correctly for a known 2-body configuration against hand-calculated values (relative error < 1e-10).

items.description: Establish baseline benchmark on Kepler orbit with Forward Euler
items.acceptance_criteria: Simulation of a Sun-Earth-like 2-body Kepler orbit for 10 orbital periods using Forward Euler with dt = 0.001 (normalized units). Record: final energy error (|dE/E0|), final angular momentum error, position error vs analytical ellipse, and wall-clock time. Results saved to results/baseline_euler.json. Energy drift expected to exceed 10% over 10 orbits.

items.description: Implement Leapfrog (Kick-Drift-Kick) symplectic integrator
items.acceptance_criteria: Leapfrog KDK integrator added to src/integrators.py. Same Kepler orbit benchmark as item_011 shows energy error bounded below 1e-6 over 10 orbits (demonstrating symplectic advantage). Test confirms leapfrog is 2nd-order by halving dt and verifying ~4x error reduction.

items.description: Implement Velocity Verlet integrator and verify equivalence to Leapfrog
items.acceptance_criteria: Velocity Verlet integrator added to src/integrators.py. Running identical initial conditions as Leapfrog produces positions matching to machine precision (< 1e-14 difference). Both integrators produce identical energy error trajectories.

items.description: Implement gravitational softening for close encounters
items.acceptance_criteria: Plummer softening parameter epsilon added to force computation: F = Gm1m2 / (r^2 + eps^2)^(3/2). Test with two bodies on collision course shows no singularity (force remains finite). Analysis of softening bias: energy error vs epsilon for at least 5 values of epsilon in [0.001, 0.1]. Results saved to results/softening_analysis.json.

items.description: Implement adaptive time-stepping for eccentric orbits
items.acceptance_criteria: Adaptive timestep controller added (e.g., based on acceleration magnitude or pairwise separation). Test on e=0.9 eccentric Kepler orbit: adaptive stepper uses fewer total steps than fixed dt while achieving equal or better energy conservation. Comparison saved to results/adaptive_stepping.json with columns: method, total_steps, final_energy_error, wall_time.

items.description: Implement Barnes-Hut tree algorithm for O(N log N) force approximation
items.acceptance_criteria: Barnes-Hut octree (3D) or quadtree (2D) in src/tree.py with configurable opening angle theta. For N=1000 random particles: force error vs direct summation < 1% for theta=0.5. Timing confirms O(N log N) scaling by measuring wall time at N = 100, 500, 1000, 5000. Results saved to results/barneshut_accuracy.json and results/barneshut_scaling.json.

items.description: Implement simple real-time or post-hoc visualization of particle trajectories
items.acceptance_criteria: Visualization module (src/visualize.py) using matplotlib that can: (a) plot particle trajectories in 2D projection, (b) animate a simulation run, (c) plot energy error over time. At least one PNG figure saved to figures/ showing a multi-body trajectory. Script callable as `python -m src.visualize <results_file>`.

items.description: Energy conservation benchmark across all integrators
items.acceptance_criteria: Run circular Kepler orbit (e=0) for 10,000 steps with Euler, Leapfrog, and Velocity Verlet at 3 different dt values each. Record |dE/E0| at each step. Results saved to results/energy_benchmark.json. Confirm Euler shows linear drift, symplectic integrators show bounded oscillation. Compare quantitatively against drift rates reported in literature (cite sources.bib).

items.description: Performance scaling benchmark: direct summation vs Barnes-Hut
items.acceptance_criteria: Measure wall-clock time per step for direct O(N^2) and Barnes-Hut at N = 50, 100, 500, 1000, 2000, 5000. Fit power-law to confirm O(N^2) and O(N log N) scaling respectively. Crossover point identified (N at which Barnes-Hut becomes faster). Results in results/scaling_benchmark.json. Plot saved to figures/scaling_comparison.png.

items.description: Validate canonical gravitational scenarios against known solutions
items.acceptance_criteria: At least 3 canonical tests implemented: (1) Circular Kepler orbit matches analytical period to < 0.1%, (2) Eccentric orbit (e=0.5) matches analytical trajectory to < 1% position error after 5 orbits, (3) Figure-eight three-body choreography (Chenciner & Montgomery 2000, cited in sources.bib) remains stable for at least 5 periods with energy error < 1e-4. Results saved to results/canonical_tests.json.

items.description: Compare simulation results against published literature values
items.acceptance_criteria: Quantitative comparison of at least 3 metrics against values reported in surveyed papers from sources.bib: (1) energy conservation rates for symplectic integrators, (2) Barnes-Hut force accuracy vs theta, (3) scaling exponents. Deviations from literature values explained. Comparison table written to results/literature_comparison.md.

items.description: Generate publication-quality figures for all experiments
items.acceptance_criteria: At least 5 figures saved to figures/ in PNG format: (1) energy error vs time for all integrators, (2) scaling comparison plot, (3) Kepler orbit trajectory, (4) figure-eight three-body trajectory, (5) Barnes-Hut accuracy vs opening angle. All figures have labeled axes, legends, titles, and consistent styling.

items.description: Write comprehensive FINDINGS.md with methodology, results, and conclusions
items.acceptance_criteria: FINDINGS.md at repo root with at least 2000 words covering: (1) problem statement, (2) methodology with algorithm descriptions, (3) experimental results with references to figures/, (4) comparison with prior work citing sources.bib, (5) conclusions and limitations. At least 8 references from sources.bib cited inline.

items.description: Create integrator comparison summary table
items.acceptance_criteria: Table in FINDINGS.md (or standalone results/integrator_summary.md) comparing all implemented integrators across: order of accuracy (measured), symplecticity (yes/no), energy drift rate, cost per step, and suitability for different orbit types. At least 4 integrators compared (Euler, Leapfrog, Verlet, and one of RK4 or adaptive).

items.description: Finalize reproducibility package and project documentation
items.acceptance_criteria: requirements.txt listing all Python dependencies with versions. README.md updated with: project overview, installation instructions, usage examples (how to run simulations and generate figures), and summary of key results. All tests pass when run via `python -m pytest tests/`. Running `python -m src.main` (or equivalent entry point) produces a complete simulation run.
